text: The Supreme Court established this principle in Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483 (1954). This landmark decision overturned the 'separate but equal' doctrine previously upheld in Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537 (1896). The Court unanimously held that the segregation of public schools violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Chief Justice Earl Warren wrote that 'separate educational facilities are inherently unequal.' The plaintiffs, led by Oliver Brown et al., successfully argued that segregation itself constituted discrimination. The decision paved the way for integration and the civil rights movement. In subsequent cases like Cooper v. Aaron, 358 U.S. 1 (1958), the Court affirmed its commitment to desegregation. As noted in the analysis in 47 Harv. L. Rev. 832, 843-44 (1934), these decisions fundamentally changed constitutional interpretation.

text: The Court held that "when a defendant demonstrates that his trial counsel 'made errors so serious that counsel was not functioning as the "counsel" guaranteed the defendant by the Sixth Amendment' and that this deficient performance prejudiced him, the defendant is entitled to relief." (citing Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984)). Justice Stevens elaborated: "The defendant must show that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's unprofessional errors [which included 'failing to investigate and present mitigating evidence' (as noted in the dissent)], the result of the proceeding would have been different." The majority further noted that "a reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome." (internal quotation marks omitted). In his dissent, Justice Scalia contended that the majority "misapplies our precedents [particularly Wiggins v. Smith and Williams v. Taylor] to create a new constitutional right to 'effective assistance of counsel' at sentencing phases" (emphasis in original).

text: The plaintiff's argument (contra the defendant's assertion in para. 4) rests on four key premises: (1) the contract was valid and enforceable; (2) the defendant breached the contract; (3) the breach was material; and (4) the plaintiff suffered damages as a result (see Section II.A. below). Although the defendant claims "substantial performance" (an affirmative defense under state law), the evidence contradicts this position! The defendant's representative stated—during a recorded meeting on April 15—that "we have no intention of fulfilling the remainder of the contract." This admission, coupled with the defendant's actions (e.g., redirecting resources to other projects, failing to meet deadlines, etc.), clearly establishes breach. Moreover, the breach was material; indeed, without the promised deliverables, the plaintiff's entire business model was compromised. The damages, therefore, are not merely the $50,000.00 specified in the liquidated damages clause, but rather the consequential damages (i.e., lost profits, damaged customer relationships, etc.) that naturally flowed from the breach.

text:
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.

This Act may be cited as the "Legal Sentence Boundary Detection Improvement Act of 2023".

SECTION 2. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act:
(1) SENTENCE BOUNDARY.—The term "sentence boundary" means the demarcation between two adjacent sentences in a text, typically indicated by a period, question mark, or exclamation point followed by a space and an uppercase letter, subject to exceptions for abbreviations, numeric expressions, and other special cases as determined by the Secretary.
(2) DETECTION ALGORITHM.—The term "detection algorithm" means a computational procedure that—
(A) analyzes text to identify sentence boundaries;
(B) considers contextual information, including but not limited to—
(i) presence of abbreviations;
(ii) presence of numeric expressions;
(iii) presence of quotation marks; and
(iv) capitalization patterns; and
(C) outputs a segmented text with clearly identified sentence boundaries.
(3) SECRETARY.—The term "Secretary" means the Secretary of Language Processing, appointed pursuant to section 5(a)(2) of the Natural Language Processing Enhancement Act (42 U.S.C. 12345).

name: Patent Claims
description: Patent claims text with extremely long sentences and technical terminology
text:
1. A method for improving sentence boundary detection in legal and technical texts, comprising: receiving, by one or more processors, an input text comprising a plurality of characters; identifying, by the one or more processors, potential sentence boundaries within the input text based on a set of predefined boundary indicators, wherein the potential sentence boundaries comprise positions in the input text where a period, question mark, or exclamation point is followed by a space and a subsequent character; analyzing, by the one or more processors, contextual features surrounding each of the potential sentence boundaries, wherein the contextual features comprise at least one of: presence of abbreviations, presence of legal citations, presence of numeric expressions, presence of quotation marks, presence of parenthetical expressions, or capitalization patterns; determining, by the one or more processors and based on the analysis of the contextual features, which of the potential sentence boundaries are actual sentence boundaries, wherein the determining comprises applying at least one machine learning model trained on annotated legal and technical texts; segmenting, by the one or more processors, the input text at the determined actual sentence boundaries to generate a plurality of sentences; and outputting, by the one or more processors, the generated plurality of sentences.

2. The method of claim 1, wherein the machine learning model comprises at least one of: a recurrent neural network (RNN), a long short-term memory (LSTM) network, a transformer network, or a bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERT) model, trained specifically on a corpus of legal and technical documents annotated with sentence boundary information.

text: As we explained in Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579, 597 (1993), Rule 702's requirement that an expert's testimony pertain to "scientific knowledge" establishes a standard of evidentiary reliability. This Court addressed the application of this standard to technical, as opposed to scientific, expert testimony in Kumho Tire Co. v. Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137 (1999). There, we explained that the gatekeeping inquiry must be tied to the facts of a particular case. Id. at 150. This Court further noted that Rule 702 was amended in response to Daubert and this Court's subsequent cases. See Fed. Rule Evid. 702, Advisory Committee Notes to 2000 Amendments. The amendment affirms the trial court's role as gatekeeper but provides that "all types of expert testimony present questions of admissibility for the trial court." Ibid. Consequently, whether the specific expert testimony on the question at issue focuses on specialized observations, the specialized translation of those observations into theory, a specialized theory itself, or the application of such a theory in a particular case, the expert's testimony often will rest "upon an experience confessedly foreign in kind to [the jury's] own." Hand, Historical and Practical Considerations Regarding Expert Testimony, 15 Harv. L. Rev. 40, 54 (1901). For this reason, the trial judge, in all cases of proffered expert testimony, must find that it is properly grounded, well-reasoned, and not speculative before it can be admitted. The trial judge must determine whether the testimony has "a reliable basis in the knowledge and experience of [the relevant] discipline." Daubert, 509 U. S., at 592.
